description: This video series examines using encrypted email communications. Many email servers store and transmit emails in a non-secure manner. This series covers how to use OpenPGP to encrypt email prior to sending it which provides for end-to-end encryption. This is a critical component in guaranteeing the confidentiality of any email communication.
name: Email Encryption
subtitle: with OpenPGP

episodes.title: Email Encryption Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:07.829
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.829 --> 00:00:10.639
Greetings, salutations and
welcome to ITProTV.

3
00:00:10.639 --> 00:00:11.707
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:11.707 --> 00:00:13.193
I'm here with Don Pezet today.

5
00:00:13.193 --> 00:00:14.410
How you doing, Don?

6
00:00:14.410 --> 00:00:15.020
>> I am doing great.

7
00:00:15.020 --> 00:00:15.810
How about yourself, Daniel?

8
00:00:15.810 --> 00:00:17.695
>> I can't complain but
sometimes I still do.

9
00:00:17.695 --> 00:00:20.610
[LAUGH]
>> Well, you can complain all you want.

10
00:00:20.610 --> 00:00:21.580
But nobody's gonna listen.

11
00:00:21.580 --> 00:00:22.600
>> Right.
>> So, [SOUND] what do we got on our

12
00:00:22.600 --> 00:00:23.410
agenda today, Daniel?

13
00:00:23.410 --> 00:00:27.356
>> Today we are going to be looking
at end-to-end encryption, and

14
00:00:27.356 --> 00:00:30.957
why we would want to do that,
and all the goodness thereof.

15
00:00:30.957 --> 00:00:34.000
So Don, what is encryption actually?

16
00:00:34.000 --> 00:00:36.540
>> Yeah, you know this is something that's
really creeping up in the news a lot

17
00:00:36.540 --> 00:00:39.570
lately, that people are starting
to recognize that you can't

18
00:00:39.570 --> 00:00:41.210
trust the networks that we use.

19
00:00:41.210 --> 00:00:44.020
You really never could, just people
are kind of realizing this now.

20
00:00:44.020 --> 00:00:48.120
So we need something to help us put
that trust back into our networks,

21
00:00:48.120 --> 00:00:50.120
and encryption is what does it, right.

22
00:00:50.120 --> 00:00:54.550
Encryption, at its heart if we just kind
of break it down to its basic function,

23
00:00:54.550 --> 00:00:59.230
is any method we can use
to secure our data so

24
00:00:59.230 --> 00:01:03.190
that nobody can read or tamper with it,

25
00:01:03.190 --> 00:01:07.100
without us either being aware or
without it even being possible at all.

26
00:01:07.100 --> 00:01:09.680
So some way to ensure that there's
nobody sitting in between.

27
00:01:09.680 --> 00:01:11.490
So if I'm sitting here and
I'm talking to you, Daniel.

28
00:01:11.490 --> 00:01:12.640
>> Right.
>> We're having a conversation.

29
00:01:12.640 --> 00:01:13.450
>> Right.

30
00:01:13.450 --> 00:01:15.830
>> Anybody in this room could
hear the conversation, and

31
00:01:15.830 --> 00:01:16.790
they'd know what was going on.

32
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:18.650
So what if we had a code?

33
00:01:18.650 --> 00:01:21.974
>> What if I said, Daniel,
the black sparrow flies at night.

34
00:01:21.974 --> 00:01:22.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well,

35
00:01:22.900 --> 00:01:24.690
that might not mean anything to anybody,
but

36
00:01:24.690 --> 00:01:28.752
to us we might have a code that says hey,
you wanna grab pizza for lunch?

37
00:01:28.752 --> 00:01:30.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> It doesn't have to be

38
00:01:30.160 --> 00:01:31.100
important data, right?

39
00:01:31.100 --> 00:01:31.920
>> Exactly.

40
00:01:31.920 --> 00:01:35.720
>> But that's a very basic
form of encryption, and

41
00:01:35.720 --> 00:01:38.040
email is an area where
that's really needed.

42
00:01:38.040 --> 00:01:40.780
>> Yeah, and email,
cause it goes over the wire.

43
00:01:40.780 --> 00:01:42.870
People can steal it, they can grab it.

44
00:01:42.870 --> 00:01:45.510
And you want that data to be encrypted so
even if they do steal and

45
00:01:45.510 --> 00:01:47.880
grab it, they are not gonna be able
to see what they're looking at.

46
00:01:47.880 --> 00:01:50.360
They're just going to see a bunch
of gibberish and skull duggery.

47
00:01:50.360 --> 00:01:51.034
>> Yep.
>> Skull duggery.

48
00:01:51.034 --> 00:01:52.760
>> Yes [LAUGH]
>> That's going to be our word of the day.

49
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:54.790
We're gonna get t-shirts
printed with that one.

50
00:01:54.790 --> 00:01:59.052
So when we deal with things like
encryption now, for those of you that have

51
00:01:59.052 --> 00:02:04.169
watched our security plus shows, or CISSP
shows, we talk about the CIA triad, right.

52
00:02:04.169 --> 00:02:08.215
The confidentiality, integrity,
and availability of security.

53
00:02:08.215 --> 00:02:10.145
Whenever you deploy a security technology,

54
00:02:10.145 --> 00:02:13.020
it should provide at least
one of those things.

55
00:02:13.020 --> 00:02:16.900
Well, encrypting your email actually
provides two of the three things, so

56
00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:18.700
this is one of the better solutions.

57
00:02:18.700 --> 00:02:20.360
The first one is confidentiality, and

58
00:02:20.360 --> 00:02:23.810
confidentiality just says,
if I send an email to somebody,

59
00:02:23.810 --> 00:02:29.350
I want to ensure that only the recipient
is able to read it, and nobody else.

60
00:02:29.350 --> 00:02:31.960
The includes the email servers and

61
00:02:31.960 --> 00:02:34.380
Internet service providers that
are in between me and them.

62
00:02:34.380 --> 00:02:37.970
That's the servers that my company hosts,
the servers that their company hosts, and

63
00:02:37.970 --> 00:02:39.320
anybody in between.

64
00:02:39.320 --> 00:02:42.995
Nobody should be able to read that email,
except for the recipient.

65
00:02:42.995 --> 00:02:45.580
And email encryption achieves that.

66
00:02:45.580 --> 00:02:46.260
>> Awesome.

67
00:02:46.260 --> 00:02:51.150
And the second part of that triad that
Don was just talking about is integrity.

68
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:54.990
That means that our data
is exactly what we put up.

69
00:02:54.990 --> 00:02:59.080
We send out an email, that email
reaches the other end and it is good,

70
00:02:59.080 --> 00:03:01.320
we know it is the exact same
email that I sent before.

71
00:03:01.320 --> 00:03:06.020
It hasn't been intercepted, modified
in any kind of way, and you get it with

72
00:03:06.020 --> 00:03:08.600
confidence and you can open that email and
know that that's your data.

73
00:03:09.860 --> 00:03:11.150
>> Yeah.
And that's pretty important,

74
00:03:11.150 --> 00:03:13.170
cuz it's easy to tamper with email.

75
00:03:13.170 --> 00:03:14.665
>> Yeah, we don't want that to happen.

76
00:03:14.665 --> 00:03:16.870
[LAUGH]
>> Now, the third one is availability,

77
00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:20.190
and encrypting your email doesn't really
provide availability there, right?

78
00:03:20.190 --> 00:03:23.880
Availability is ensuring that a service
is functioning when you need it.

79
00:03:23.880 --> 00:03:26.980
Well, that really comes
down to redundancy and

80
00:03:26.980 --> 00:03:29.710
other technologies like that on
the mail servers, themselves.

81
00:03:29.710 --> 00:03:31.060
So we're not gonna get that one.

82
00:03:31.060 --> 00:03:32.710
>> Yeah.
>> We do get two of the others.

83
00:03:32.710 --> 00:03:36.580
And that means that this is a great
security technology to deploy.

84
00:03:36.580 --> 00:03:37.350
All right?

85
00:03:37.350 --> 00:03:40.266
Daniel, why do we even need to worry about
encrypting our email in the first place?

86
00:03:40.266 --> 00:03:42.355
If I send an email to to you.

87
00:03:42.355 --> 00:03:43.841
>> Yeah.
>> You get it.

88
00:03:43.841 --> 00:03:45.502
It goes in your mailbox.
It doesn't go in anybody else's

89
00:03:45.502 --> 00:03:46.230
mailbox, right?

90
00:03:46.230 --> 00:03:47.460
So why bother encrypting it?

91
00:03:47.460 --> 00:03:49.430
>> Well,
you would think that that would be plenty.

92
00:03:49.430 --> 00:03:50.160
That's all you need.

93
00:03:50.160 --> 00:03:51.770
The server sends you an email.

94
00:03:51.770 --> 00:03:53.490
Who cares about looking at your email?

95
00:03:53.490 --> 00:03:58.480
Well there are certain situations where
you may want to keep that data secure.

96
00:03:58.480 --> 00:03:59.970
It may be private information.

97
00:03:59.970 --> 00:04:03.360
It could be Social Security cards,
birthdates, mother's maiden name,

98
00:04:03.360 --> 00:04:06.850
your favorite band, whatever the case may
be, you wanna keep something secured.

99
00:04:06.850 --> 00:04:10.540
You might work for a government agency,
could be in the military, you might work

100
00:04:10.540 --> 00:04:15.160
for an RND company where that research is
intellectual property you don't want other

101
00:04:15.160 --> 00:04:19.160
people getting a hold of that RND and
then creating a competing product.

102
00:04:19.160 --> 00:04:23.300
So, that is the reason that we'd
like to encrypt our emails.

103
00:04:23.300 --> 00:04:26.580
>> And the thing we have to remember
is that the email infrastructures on

104
00:04:26.580 --> 00:04:29.950
the internet,
it was developed over thirty years ago,

105
00:04:29.950 --> 00:04:32.920
and it was a much
different world back then.

106
00:04:32.920 --> 00:04:35.260
Right, networks were a lot safer and
simpler,

107
00:04:35.260 --> 00:04:37.770
and people didn't worry
about security like they do.

108
00:04:37.770 --> 00:04:41.900
So all email transported on
the Internet is transported using

109
00:04:41.900 --> 00:04:43.790
a protocol called SMTP.

110
00:04:43.790 --> 00:04:46.000
The simple mail transport protocol.

111
00:04:46.000 --> 00:04:49.870
>> And SMTP sends email in plain text.

112
00:04:49.870 --> 00:04:52.780
It doesn't do any encoding or
encrypting by default.

113
00:04:52.780 --> 00:04:55.520
It can be set to do encoding,
but that's not encryption.

114
00:04:55.520 --> 00:04:58.452
Encoding just means it makes it
more compact, so it's smaller, and

115
00:04:58.452 --> 00:04:59.166
more reliable.

116
00:04:59.166 --> 00:05:02.237
But anybody can decode if
it's uuencoded or Base64 or

117
00:05:02.237 --> 00:05:04.274
any of those crazy things out there.

118
00:05:04.274 --> 00:05:05.597
It's super easy to reverse those.

119
00:05:05.597 --> 00:05:11.360
So when you send an email, it's traveling
across the network in plain text.

120
00:05:11.360 --> 00:05:16.450
That means any email server and
any network or Internet service provider,

121
00:05:16.450 --> 00:05:20.670
anybody in between you and your
destination, they can capture that traffic

122
00:05:20.670 --> 00:05:24.230
with like a packet sniffer, and
they can read your emails right there,

123
00:05:24.230 --> 00:05:26.270
while that data is in transit,
it is in plain text.

124
00:05:27.320 --> 00:05:28.330
Compounding that,

125
00:05:28.330 --> 00:05:32.980
once it gets to a server, most of our
servers will store it in plain text.

126
00:05:32.980 --> 00:05:39.220
If you're using SendMail, or Microsoft
Exchange, or any of the various email

127
00:05:39.220 --> 00:05:42.780
servers that are out there, the majority
of them store the data in plain text.

128
00:05:42.780 --> 00:05:46.350
Sure it might be in a database, but
it's not secured in that database.

129
00:05:46.350 --> 00:05:47.460
So the data can be accessed and

130
00:05:47.460 --> 00:05:50.460
people can read your email, whoever
is an administrator for that server.

131
00:05:50.460 --> 00:05:55.060
So we need ways to ensure that
when we throw an email out there.

132
00:05:55.060 --> 00:05:58.012
That it is secured end to end.

133
00:05:58.012 --> 00:05:59.150
Now let's talk about that Daniel.

134
00:05:59.150 --> 00:06:00.502
>> Yeah.
>> Because as our data,

135
00:06:00.502 --> 00:06:04.427
as our email moves across the Internet, it
passes through a few different places like

136
00:06:04.427 --> 00:06:05.372
servers-
>> Right.

137
00:06:05.372 --> 00:06:08.463
>> and clients and all that so, we have
to think about all those different steps

138
00:06:08.463 --> 00:06:11.665
along the journey, which is where
the end-to-end term comes from, right?

139
00:06:11.665 --> 00:06:12.245
>> That is correct.

140
00:06:12.245 --> 00:06:16.760
So what types of encryption do we have,
Don?

141
00:06:16.760 --> 00:06:19.428
I'm sure there are multiple
types of encryption,

142
00:06:19.428 --> 00:06:23.595
we have server based encryption and
different other types of things like that.

143
00:06:23.595 --> 00:06:26.520
Give us an overview of what
kind of encryption we have.

144
00:06:26.520 --> 00:06:30.146
>> All right so, when you talk about
encryption it may be something that you

145
00:06:30.146 --> 00:06:34.136
have to provide, it may be something
that you're service provider provides.

146
00:06:34.136 --> 00:06:35.738
I guess that's why they
call it providers right?

147
00:06:35.738 --> 00:06:37.178
>> [LAUGH] Providers.
>> So they might do it.

148
00:06:37.178 --> 00:06:39.850
And so you'll hear about people say like,
oh yeah,

149
00:06:39.850 --> 00:06:43.420
our email server stores all of your
emails fully encrypted, right.

150
00:06:43.420 --> 00:06:45.080
Well, what does that do for you?

151
00:06:45.080 --> 00:06:48.270
Well, what they're doing is
what's called data at rest.

152
00:06:48.270 --> 00:06:52.247
While your data is stored in their
mailbox server, it's encrypted, right.

153
00:06:53.440 --> 00:06:56.990
But when they send the email along,
when they forward it to somebody else,

154
00:06:56.990 --> 00:07:00.100
whoever the destination
is it's gotta use SMTP.

155
00:07:00.100 --> 00:07:01.980
And it's gotta be
unencrypted at that point.

156
00:07:01.980 --> 00:07:05.890
So the email might be stored
at rest encrypted, but

157
00:07:05.890 --> 00:07:09.160
that server based encryption does
not help you within transit.

158
00:07:09.160 --> 00:07:11.690
And in transit's where your
data's really at risk.

159
00:07:11.690 --> 00:07:13.065
And that's that next solution is,

160
00:07:13.065 --> 00:07:17.420
is your service provider might say well
we secure your email in transit too.

161
00:07:17.420 --> 00:07:22.650
They might use SSL or TLS, technologies
like that coupled with SMTP to

162
00:07:22.650 --> 00:07:25.380
encrypt the data as it moves
from server to server.

163
00:07:25.380 --> 00:07:29.390
But the problem there is they only
control security from their server

164
00:07:29.390 --> 00:07:30.820
to the next hop.

165
00:07:30.820 --> 00:07:34.185
If you have to pass through more than one
server, they don't have control over that.

166
00:07:34.185 --> 00:07:38.910
SMTP wasn't designed to handle that,
and so the encryption technologies that

167
00:07:38.910 --> 00:07:41.080
are tacked on to SMTP are exactly that,
they're tacked on.

168
00:07:41.080 --> 00:07:44.620
They're hacks that are just added and
they're not terribly effective.

169
00:07:44.620 --> 00:07:49.470
So you can't really guarantee, even when
you use a service like Google, right.

170
00:07:49.470 --> 00:07:54.030
Gmail, where they do SSL to the web based
email box, and then they do encryption on

171
00:07:54.030 --> 00:07:57.490
their database on the back end,
well Google's got the keys for that.

172
00:07:57.490 --> 00:07:58.830
You're trusting them.

173
00:07:58.830 --> 00:07:59.700
They can read your emails.

174
00:07:59.700 --> 00:08:02.330
That's how they show the relevant
ads in your mailbox, right?

175
00:08:02.330 --> 00:08:04.260
They actively read your emails.

176
00:08:04.260 --> 00:08:07.320
So you're trusting
somebody else to do that.

177
00:08:07.320 --> 00:08:09.290
And most of us, we want more, right?

178
00:08:09.290 --> 00:08:12.960
We want something where, we don't have
to trust anybody but ourselves, right?

179
00:08:12.960 --> 00:08:17.592
What was it, was it Ben Franklin who said
two men can keep a secret if one is dead?

180
00:08:17.592 --> 00:08:19.190
Right?
>> [LAUGH] Yes, that's exactly right.

181
00:08:19.190 --> 00:08:20.810
>> So that's how email should be, right?

182
00:08:20.810 --> 00:08:22.170
>> That's exactly how email should be.

183
00:08:22.170 --> 00:08:27.940
So Don, is there a type of encryption
that we can use that would ensure

184
00:08:27.940 --> 00:08:30.280
when it's static, when it's still.

185
00:08:30.280 --> 00:08:32.100
And also in motion?

186
00:08:32.100 --> 00:08:32.760
>> Absolutely.

187
00:08:32.760 --> 00:08:33.720
>> Awesome.
>> And

188
00:08:33.720 --> 00:08:38.550
what we have to do, is we have to take
charge of the encryption ourself, right?

189
00:08:38.550 --> 00:08:40.220
You can't trust your
email service provider.

190
00:08:40.220 --> 00:08:42.890
You can't trust your Internet
service provider, your network.

191
00:08:42.890 --> 00:08:44.720
You can't trust any of that stuff.

192
00:08:44.720 --> 00:08:45.680
Can trust yourself.

193
00:08:45.680 --> 00:08:47.362
>> It pays to be paranoid
in this business.

194
00:08:47.362 --> 00:08:48.990
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Sad, but true, right?

195
00:08:48.990 --> 00:08:49.560
>> Yes, it is.

196
00:08:49.560 --> 00:08:50.795
>> This is gonna be my quote episode.

197
00:08:50.795 --> 00:08:52.283
>> [LAUGH]
>> It was Kurt Cobain who said,

198
00:08:52.283 --> 00:08:54.696
just because you're paranoid
doesn't mean they're not after you.

199
00:08:54.696 --> 00:08:55.601
>> Doesn't mean they're not following,
yeah.

200
00:08:55.601 --> 00:08:57.110
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So, that's how this is.

201
00:08:57.110 --> 00:09:00.630
We need some kinda technology
that will do that, and

202
00:09:00.630 --> 00:09:04.240
that's what this tech
skills series is all about.

203
00:09:04.240 --> 00:09:05.010
We're gonna highlight, or

204
00:09:05.010 --> 00:09:05.870
Daniel's gonna highlight,
>> Yeah.

205
00:09:05.870 --> 00:09:08.390
>> Several of the different
technologies out there that we can use.

206
00:09:08.390 --> 00:09:10.630
Where we control the encryption.

207
00:09:10.630 --> 00:09:14.000
Now it's encrypted even before
it gets to the mail server.

208
00:09:14.000 --> 00:09:16.440
And even before it crosses the Internet,
it's encrypted.

209
00:09:16.440 --> 00:09:18.120
So we get end-to-end encryption.

210
00:09:18.120 --> 00:09:21.140
It's encrypted from the point
that it leaves your machine to

211
00:09:21.140 --> 00:09:22.800
the point that the recipient reads it.

212
00:09:22.800 --> 00:09:25.750
And everybody in between is
not able to access that data.

213
00:09:25.750 --> 00:09:26.460
>> Yes sir.

214
00:09:26.460 --> 00:09:31.660
And the type of encryption that we're
gonna be using to cover that is PGP,

215
00:09:31.660 --> 00:09:35.530
which has been the standard encryption for
quite a while now.

216
00:09:35.530 --> 00:09:36.200
>> A long time.

217
00:09:36.200 --> 00:09:36.830
>> A long time.

218
00:09:36.830 --> 00:09:40.600
It started off as an open source product,
then it got bought and

219
00:09:40.600 --> 00:09:41.710
became a closed source product.

220
00:09:41.710 --> 00:09:46.055
And the guy that actually created
the PGP encryption algorithm,

221
00:09:46.055 --> 00:09:49.940
created the new open source
using the same basic idea.

222
00:09:49.940 --> 00:09:52.640
And that is freely available to all of us,

223
00:09:52.640 --> 00:09:55.030
which is what we're gonna use
to do that type of encryption.

224
00:09:56.040 --> 00:09:59.040
>> So in this series we're gonna start
out by showing that one right, OpenPGP.

225
00:09:59.040 --> 00:10:02.140
That's probably the best of
the solutions that we'll talk about.

226
00:10:02.140 --> 00:10:05.690
And we'll get a chance to see that
from Windows, as well as Linux,

227
00:10:05.690 --> 00:10:06.790
as well as Mac OS.

228
00:10:06.790 --> 00:10:09.770
Right, so seeing these different
platforms all use PGP,

229
00:10:09.770 --> 00:10:13.510
and the cool part about it is,
it's not tied to just email.
